response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second, third, and fifth circuits. [CHUNK_6] This program is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [CHUNK_7] The bill requires the judiciary to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the governor and legislature prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028, and the Act will be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_17]",
  "appropriations": "There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ (HB727) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_10] The unspecified sums are for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions. [CHUNK_11] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_13]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The provided legislative documents do not specify the assumptions or methodology used to determine the necessary appropriation amount for the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_10] The bill leaves the appropriation amount blank for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027. [CHUNK_11] The cost estimation methods and data sources used for financial projections are not detailed in the bill. [CHUNK_10]",
  "agency_impact": "There is established within the second, third, and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_7] The bill requires the establishment of seven temporary positions, including social worker V, social worker IV, circuit court clerk II, and judicial clerk positions to support the program. [CHUNK_12] The judiciary shall be responsible for expending the appropriated sums and must submit annual reports on the program's status and recommendations to the legislature. [CHUNK_13]",
  "economic_impact": "The pilot program aims to provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [CHUNK_8] By focusing on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism, the program may reduce long-term costs associated with incarceration. [CHUNK_4] As of August 2024, a similar program in the first circuit had twenty-three women participating. [CHUNK_5]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act builds upon Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, which established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. [CHUNK_3] It expands this initiative by establishing a temporary three-year woman's court pilot program within the second, third, and fifth circuits. [CHUNK_18] The judiciary's recommendations will determine whether the pilot program should continue, expand, or be discontinued after its repeal date of June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_16]",
  "revenue_sources": "There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for the program. [CHUNK_10] The bill specifies this appropriation is for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_11] No other revenue sources are mentioned in the provided document. [CHUNK_10]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The bill appropriates an unspecified sum from the general revenues for fiscal year 2025-2026. [CHUNK_10] The same unspecified sum is appropriated for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_11] These funds are for equipment, mental health and substance abuse treatment services, and the establishment of seven temporary positions. [CHUNK_11] The temporary positions include social worker V, social worker IV, circuit court clerk II, and judicial clerk positions. [CHUNK_12] The Act establishes a three-year pilot program, but appropriations are only specified for the first two fiscal years. [CHUNK_11] The program is set to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_17] The judiciary is required to submit a report with recommendations on whether the program should continue, expand, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_16] Any fiscal implications beyond the three-year pilot period are contingent on future legislative action based on these recommendations. [CHUNK_16]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided legislative document does not indicate any anticipated impact on the State's operating revenues. [CHUNK_10] The bill focuses on appropriations from general revenues to fund the program. [CHUNK_10] No fees, fines, or other revenue-generating mechanisms are described in the Act. [CHUNK_10]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative document does not specify any capital expenditures for the program. [CHUNK_11] The appropriation is designated for equipment, services, and temporary positions, which are typically considered operating expenses. [CHUNK_11] There is no mention of facility construction, renovation, or other capital projects. [CHUNK_11]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The women's court pilot program is established as a temporary, three-year program scheduled to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_17] The judiciary is required to submit recommendations regarding whether the program should continue, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_16] Any ongoing fiscal obligations after the pilot period will depend entirely on future legislation based on these recommendations. [CHUNK_16]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. [CHUNK_0]",
  "fte_positions": "The bill provides for the establishment of seven temporary positions. [CHUNK_11] These positions include an unspecified number of full-time equivalent (FTE) social worker V positions, social worker IV positions, circuit court clerk II positions, and judicial clerk positions. [CHUNK_12] The specific allocation of the seven FTE positions among the different roles is not detailed in the bill. [CHUNK_12]",
  "appropriations_changes": "No previous version of the bill was provided, so changes to appropriations cannot be identified. [CHUNK_0] The bill appropriates an unspecified sum of money ($) from the general fund for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_10] The appropriation is for equipment, services, and seven temporary positions. [CHUNK_11]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "No previous version of the bill was provided, so changes to funding sources cannot be identified. [CHUNK_0] The bill specifies that the appropriation is made out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_10] There is no mention of any other funding sources or changes from previous funding methods. [CHUNK_10]",
  "department_impact": "No previous version of the bill was provided, so changes to departmental responsibility cannot be identified. [CHUNK_0] The bill states that the women's court pilot program is established within the second, third, and fifth circuits of the judiciary. [CHUNK_7] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_13]",
  "reports_required": "The judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation, to the governor and legislature. [CHUNK_13] This report is required no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028. [CHUNK_14] The report must include the status of the program, participant numbers, and recommendations as to whether the pilot program should be continued, expanded, or discontinued. [CHUNK_16]",
  "pilot_program": "The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second, third, and fifth circuits. [CHUNK_6] The bill consistently refers to the program as a pilot program. [CHUNK_7] This new pilot program is modeled after a similar three-year pilot program in the first circuit established by Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022. [CHUNK_3]",
  "sunset_date": "This Act shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_17] The bill's description confirms it sunsets on 6/30/2028. [CHUNK_18]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_17] No information regarding a defective or changed effective date from a previous version is provided. [CHUNK_17]"
}

[CHUNK_6] This program is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [CHUNK_7] The bill requires the judiciary to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the governor and legislature prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028, and the Act will be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_10] The unspecified sums are for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions. [CHUNK_17] The judiciary is required to submit a report with recommendations on whether the program should continue, expand, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_16] Any fiscal implications beyond the three-year pilot period are contingent on future legislative action based on these recommendations. [CHUNK_16]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided legislative document does not indicate any anticipated impact on the State's operating revenues. [CHUNK_10] The bill focuses on appropriations from general revenues to fund the program. [CHUNK_10] No fees, fines, or other revenue-generating mechanisms are described in the Act. [CHUNK_10]",

[CHUNK_17] The judiciary is required to submit recommendations regarding whether the program should continue, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_16] Any ongoing fiscal obligations after the pilot period will depend entirely on future legislation based on these recommendations. [CHUNK_16]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. [CHUNK_0]",
  "fte_positions": "The bill provides for the establishment of seven temporary positions. [CHUNK_11] These positions include an unspecified number of full-time equivalent (FTE) social worker V positions, social worker IV positions, circuit court clerk II positions, and judicial clerk positions. chunk_details.chunk_text: HB727 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 727 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to the women's court . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number

that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai â€˜ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and

of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience

have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This

program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January of 2023, with

The program began accepting participants in January of 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August, 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this

participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second, third, and fifth circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their

lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. SECTION 2. (a) There is established within the second, third, and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental

program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9)

Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. SECTION 3. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much

fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions as follows: (1) full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker V positions; (2) full-time equivalent

equivalent ( FTE) social worker V positions; (2) full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker IV positions; (3) full-time equivalent ( FTE) circuit court clerk II positions; and (4) full-time equivalent ( FTE) judicial clerk positions; for the women's court pilot program established pursuant to section 2 of this Act. The

program established pursuant to section 2 of this Act. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. SECTION 4. The judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation, to the governor and legislature no later than forty

legislation, to the governor and legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028 , regarding: (1) The status of the women's court pilot program; (2) The number of women accepted into the pilot program; (3) The number of women

accepted into the pilot program; (3) The number of women who were eligible to participate in the pilot program but who could not be accepted into the program because of program limitations; (4) The number of women completing the pilot program; (5) The number of women who were removed from

program; (5) The number of women who were removed from the pilot program; and (6) Recommendations as to whether the women's court pilot program should: (A) Continue as a pilot program; (B) Expand to include additional participants; (C) Provide additional services; or (D) Be discontinued. SECTION 5. This Act shall

services; or (D) Be discontinued. SECTION 5. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025, and shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. INTRODUCED BY: _____________________________ Report Title: Women's Court Pilot Program; Report; Appropriation Description: Establishes a temporary three-year woman's court pilot program within the second, third, and fifth

woman's court pilot program within the second, third, and fifth circuits. Establishes temporary positions. Requires a report. Appropriates funds. Sunsets 6/30/2028. The summary description of legislation appearing on this page is for informational purposes only and is not legislation or evidence of legislative intent.

overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

HB727.chunk_text: HB727 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 727 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to the women's court . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number

that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai â€˜ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and

of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience

have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This

program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January of 2023, with

The program began accepting participants in January of 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August, 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this

participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second, third, and fifth circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their

lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. SECTION 2. (a) There is established within the second, third, and fifth circuits of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental

program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9)

Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. SECTION 3. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much

fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for equipment; mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services; and the establishment of seven temporary positions as follows: (1) full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker V positions; (2) full-time equivalent

equivalent ( FTE) social worker V positions; (2) full-time equivalent ( FTE) social worker IV positions; (3) full-time equivalent ( FTE) circuit court clerk II positions; and (4) full-time equivalent ( FTE) judicial clerk positions; for the women's court pilot program established pursuant to section 2 of this Act. program established pursuant to section 2 of this Act. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. SECTION 4. legislation, to the governor and legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028 , regarding: (1) The status of the women's court pilot program; (2) The number of women accepted into the pilot program; (3) The number of women
